cells.reasonOutOfScope: Threats identified in DDF Platform threat model.

threats.title: Spoofing the OpenSearch Endpoint Process
threats.description: OpenSearch Endpoint may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to information disclosure by External OpenSearch Client. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the destination process.
threats.mitigation: All endpoints use standard authentication mechanisms and TLS

threats.title: Spoofing the External OpenSearch Client External Entity
threats.description: External OpenSearch Client may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to unauthorized access to OpenSearch Endpoint. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the external entity.
threats.mitigation: All endpoints use standard authentication mechanisms and TLS

threats.title: Potential Lack of Input Validation for OpenSearch Endpoint
threats.description: Data flowing across Request may be tampered with by an attacker. This may lead to a denial of service attack against OpenSearch Endpoint or an elevation of privilege attack against OpenSearch Endpoint or an information disclosure by OpenSearch Endpoint. Failure to verify that input is as expected is a root cause of a very large number of exploitable issues. Consider all paths and the way they handle data. Verify that all input is verified for correctness using an approved list input validation approach.
threats.mitigation: All input is validated by the Catalog Framework

threats.title: Potential Data Repudiation by OpenSearch Endpoint
threats.description: OpenSearch Endpoint claims that it did not receive data from a source outside the trust boundary. Consider using logging or auditing to record the source, time, and summary of the received data.
threats.mitigation: All connections are audited.

threats.title: Data Flow Sniffing
threats.description: Data flowing across Request may be sniffed by an attacker. Depending on what type of data an attacker can read, it may be used to attack other parts of the system or simply be a disclosure of information leading to compliance violations. Consider encrypting the data flow.
threats.mitigation: TLS

threats.title: Potential Process Crash or Stop for OpenSearch Endpoint
threats.description: OpenSearch Endpoint crashes, halts, stops or runs slowly; in all cases violating an availability metric.
threats.mitigation: OpenSearch Endpoint is not a process on the system, it is a service running within a container that is managing services.

threats.title: Data Flow Request Is Potentially Interrupted
threats.description: An external agent interrupts data flowing across a trust boundary in either direction.
threats.mitigation: DDF is a software system is not responsible for the network.

threats.title: Elevation Using Impersonation
threats.description: OpenSearch Endpoint may be able to impersonate the context of External OpenSearch Client in order to gain additional privilege.
threats.mitigation: OpenSearch REST Endpoint would have similar or more privilege than any external client already.

threats.title: OpenSearch Endpoint May be Subject to Elevation of Privilege Using Remote Code Execution
threats.description: External OpenSearch Client may be able to remotely execute code for OpenSearch Endpoint.
threats.mitigation: The OpenSearch client only communicates with the OpenSearch endpoint over a well defined API.

cells.reasonOutOfScope: Within the trust boundary of the DDF.  These two processes communicate via Java calls on the same JVM.
Within the trust boundary of the DDF.  These two processes communicate via Java calls on the same JVM.

threats.title: Spoofing of the External OpenSearch Client External Destination Entity
threats.description: External OpenSearch Client may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to data being sent to the attacker's target instead of External OpenSearch Client. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the external entity.
threats.mitigation: All endpoints use standard authentication mechanisms and TLS

threats.title: External Entity External OpenSearch Client Potentially Denies Receiving Data
threats.description: External OpenSearch Client claims that it did not receive data from a process on the other side of the trust boundary. Consider using logging or auditing to record the source, time, and summary of the received data.
threats.mitigation: Everything sent to and received from sources is audited

threats.title: Data Flow Response Is Potentially Interrupted
threats.description: An external agent interrupts data flowing across a trust boundary in either direction.
threats.mitigation: DDF is a software system is not responsible for the network.

cells.reasonOutOfScope: Within the trust boundary of the DDF.  These two processes communicate via Java calls on the same JVM.

threats.title: Spoofing of the External REST Service External Destination Entity
threats.description: External REST Service may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to data being sent to the attacker's target instead of External REST Service. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the external entity.
threats.mitigation: All endpoints use standard authentication mechanisms and TLS

threats.title: External Entity External REST Service Potentially Denies Receiving Data
threats.description: External REST Service claims that it did not receive data from a process on the other side of the trust boundary. Consider using logging or auditing to record the source, time, and summary of the received data.
threats.mitigation: Everything sent to and received from sources is audited

threats.title: Data Flow Post Is Potentially Interrupted
threats.description: An external agent interrupts data flowing across a trust boundary in either direction.
threats.mitigation: DDF is a software system is not responsible for the network

cells.reasonOutOfScope: Within the trust boundary of the DDF.  These two processes communicate via Java calls on the same JVM.

threats.title: Spoofing of the External OpenSearch Service External Destination Entity
threats.description: External OpenSearch Service may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to data being sent to the attacker's target instead of External OpenSearch Service. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the external entity.
threats.mitigation: All endpoints use standard authentication mechanisms and TLS

threats.title: External Entity External OpenSearch Service Potentially Denies Receiving Data
threats.description: External OpenSearch Service claims that it did not receive data from a process on the other side of the trust boundary. Consider using logging or auditing to record the source, time, and summary of the received data.
threats.mitigation: Everything sent to and received from sources is audited

threats.title: Data Flow Query Is Potentially Interrupted
threats.description: An external agent interrupts data flowing across a trust boundary in either direction.
threats.mitigation: DDF is a software system is not responsible for the network.

threats.title: Spoofing the OpenSearch Source Process
threats.description: OpenSearch Source may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to information disclosure by External OpenSearch Service. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the destination process.
threats.mitigation: All endpoints use standard authentication mechanisms and TLS

threats.title: Spoofing the External OpenSearch Service External Entity
threats.description: External OpenSearch Service may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to unauthorized access to OpenSearch Source. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the external entity.
threats.mitigation: All endpoints use standard authentication mechanisms and TLS

threats.title: Potential Lack of Input Validation for OpenSearch Source
threats.description: Data flowing across Response may be tampered with by an attacker. This may lead to a denial of service attack against OpenSearch Source or an elevation of privilege attack against OpenSearch Source or an information disclosure by OpenSearch Source. Failure to verify that input is as expected is a root cause of a very large number of exploitable issues. Consider all paths and the way they handle data. Verify that all input is verified for correctness using an approved list input validation approach.
threats.mitigation: All input is validated by the Catalog Framework

threats.title: Potential Data Repudiation by OpenSearch Source
threats.description: OpenSearch Source claims that it did not receive data from a source outside the trust boundary. Consider using logging or auditing to record the source, time, and summary of the received data.
threats.mitigation: All connections are audited.

threats.title: Data Flow Sniffing
threats.description: Data flowing across Response may be sniffed by an attacker. Depending on what type of data an attacker can read, it may be used to attack other parts of the system or simply be a disclosure of information leading to compliance violations. Consider encrypting the data flow.
threats.mitigation: TLS

threats.title: Potential Process Crash or Stop for OpenSearch Source
threats.description: OpenSearch Source crashes, halts, stops or runs slowly; in all cases violating an availability metric.
threats.mitigation: OpenSearch Source is not a process on the system, it is a service running within a container that is managing services.

threats.title: Data Flow Response Is Potentially Interrupted
threats.description: An external agent interrupts data flowing across a trust boundary in either direction.
threats.mitigation: DDF is a software system is not responsible for the network.

threats.title: Elevation Using Impersonation
threats.description: OpenSearch Source may be able to impersonate the context of External OpenSearch Service in order to gain additional privilege.
threats.mitigation: OpenSearch Source executes only with the permissions of the user that is requesting the resource.

threats.title: OpenSearch Source May be Subject to Elevation of Privilege Using Remote Code Execution
threats.description: External OpenSearch Service may be able to remotely execute code for OpenSearch Source.
threats.mitigation: Unsolicted responses are not allowed and the service only communicates over a well defined API.

threats.title: Elevation by Changing the Execution Flow in OpenSearch Source
threats.description: An attacker may pass data into OpenSearch Source in order to change the flow of program execution within OpenSearch Source to the attacker's choosing.
threats.mitigation: All endpoints use standard authentication mechanisms and only operations the user is allowed to carry out are executed.

cells.reasonOutOfScope: Within the trust boundary of the DDF.  These two processes communicate via Java calls on the same JVM.
Within the trust boundary of the DDF.  These two processes communicate via Java calls on the same JVM.

threats.title: Tampering threat against Request
threats.description: Attacker could tamper with the bits being sent across the wire.
threats.mitigation: Use TLS with mutual authentication and digital signatures.

threats.title: Information Disclosure threat against Request
threats.description: Attacker could intercept the bytes that are being transmitted across the wire.
threats.mitigation: Encrypt data using TLS with mutual authentication and digital signatures.

threats.title: Denial Of Service threat against Request
threats.description: An external agent interrupts data flowing across a trust boundary in either direction.
threats.mitigation: DDF is a software system is not responsible for the network.

threats.title: Tampering threat against Response.
threats.description: Attacker could tamper with the bits being sent across the wire.
threats.mitigation: Use TLS with mutual authentication and digital signatures.

threats.title: Potential Lack of Input Validation for Confluence Source
threats.description: Data flowing across Response may be tampered with by an attacker. This may lead to a denial of service attack against Confluence Source or an elevation of privilege attack against Confluence Source or an information disclosure by Confluence Source. Failure to verify that input is as expected is a root cause of a very large number of exploitable issues. Consider all paths and the way they handle data. Verify that all input is verified for correctness using an approved list input validation approach.
threats.mitigation: All input is validated by the Catalog Framework

threats.title: Repudiation threat against External Confluence Service
threats.description: Confluence Source claims that it did not receive data from a source outside the trust boundary. Consider using logging or auditing to record the source, time, and summary of the received data.
threats.mitigation: This threat does not apply because it is mitigated by Confluence's safeguards against repudiation.

threats.title: Information Disclosure threat against Response
threats.description: Attackers could intercept the bytes that are being transmitted across the wire.
threats.mitigation: Encrypt data using TLS with mutual authentication and digital signatures.

threats.title: Denial of Service threat against Response
threats.description: Confluence Source crashes, halts, stops or runs slowly; in all cases violating an availability metric.
threats.mitigation: Confluence Source is not a process on the system, it is a service running within a container that is managing services..

threats.title: Elevation Using Impersonation
threats.description: Confluence Source may be able to impersonate the context of External Confluence Query Service in order to gain additional privilege.
threats.mitigation: Confluence Source executes only with the permissions of the user that is requesting the resource.

threats.title: Elevation by Changing the Execution Flow in Confluence Source
threats.description: An attacker may pass data into Confluence Source in order to change the flow of program execution within Confluence Source to the attacker's choosing.
threats.mitigation: All endpoints use standard authentication mechanisms and only operations the user is allowed to carry out are executed.

threats.title: Spoofing threat against External Confluence Service
threats.description: Confluence Source may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to information disclosure by External Confluence Query Service. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the destination process. Attacker could set up malicious service to recieve requests from the Catalog and provide malicious responses.
threats.mitigation: Use TLS with mutual authentication.

threats.title: Data Flow Response Is Potentially Interrupted
threats.description: An external agent interrupts data flowing across a trust boundary in either direction.
threats.mitigation: DDF is a software system is not responsible for the network.

threats.title: Confluence Source May be Subject to Elevation of Privilege Using Remote Code Execution
threats.description: External Confluence Query Service may be able to remotely execute code for Confluence Source.
threats.mitigation: The external service cannot send unsolicited responses to the Source and then communicate over a well defined API.

cells.reasonOutOfScope: Within the trust boundary of the DDF.  These two processes communicate via Java calls on the same JVM.

threats.description: Confluence Source claims that it did not receive data from a source outside the trust boundary. Consider using logging or auditing to record the source, time, and summary of the received data.

threats.title: Potential Process Crash or Stop for Confluence Source

threats.title: Elevation by Changing the Execution Flow in Confluence Source
threats.description: An attacker may pass data into Confluence Source in order to change the flow of program execution within Confluence Source to the attacker's choosing.

threats.title: Spoofing the External Confluence Product Service External Entity
threats.description: External Confluence Product Service may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to unauthorized access to Confluence Source. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the external entity.
threats.mitigation: All endpoints use standard authentication mechanisms and TLS

threats.title: Denial Of Service threat against Response
threats.description: Attacker could cause remote resource to send back huge responses that bring the system down.
threats.mitigation:
"1. Use network devices that have rate-limiting capabilities.
2. Use TLS with mutual authentication. This threat does not apply, because it is mitigated via the Confluence Source's safeguards against Denial of Service."

threats.title: Elevation Using Impersonation
threats.description: Confluence Source may be able to impersonate the context of External Confluence Product Service in order to gain additional privilege.
threats.mitigation: Confluence Source executes only with the permissions of the user that is requesting the resource.

threats.title: Confluence Source May be Subject to Elevation of Privilege Using Remote Code Execution
threats.description: External Confluence Product Service may be able to remotely execute code for Confluence Source.
threats.mitigation: Unsolicited responses are not allowed and communication happens over a well defined API.

cells.reasonOutOfScope: Within the trust boundary of the DDF.  These two processes communicate via Java calls on the same JVM.

threats.title: Spoofing of the Remote Resource External Destination Entity
threats.description:
Potential Excessive Resource Consumption for URL Resource Reader or File System
ing
threats.mitigation: Denial Of Service

threats.title: Potential Excessive Resource Consumption for URL Resource Reader or File System
threats.description: Does URL Resource Reader or File System take explicit steps to control resource consumption? Resource consumption attacks can be hard to deal with, and there are times that it makes sense to let the OS do the job. Be careful that your resource requests don't deadlock, and that they do timeout.
threats.mitigation: Resource requests have timeouts

threats.title: Spoofing of the Remote Resource External Destination Entity
threats.description: Remote Resource may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to data being sent to the attacker's target instead of Remote Resource. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the external entity.
threats.mitigation: All endpoints use standard authentication mechanisms and TLS

threats.title: External Entity Remote Resource Potentially Denies Receiving Data
threats.description: Remote Resource claims that it did not receive data from a process on the other side of the trust boundary. Consider using logging or auditing to record the source, time, and summary of the received data.
threats.mitigation: Everything sent to and received from sources is audited

threats.title: Data Flow Retrieve Resource Is Potentially Interrupted
threats.description: An external agent interrupts data flowing across a trust boundary in either direction.
threats.mitigation: Resources are cached and automatically restarted/retried on failures. DDF is a software system is not responsible for the network.

threats.title: Spoofing the URL Resource Reader Process
threats.description: URL Resource Reader may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to unauthorized access to File System. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the source process.
threats.mitigation: All endpoints use standard authentication mechanisms and TLS

threats.title: The File System Data Store Could Be Corrupted
threats.description: Data flowing across Retrieve Resource may be tampered with by an attacker. This may lead to corruption of File System. Ensure the integrity of the data flow to the data store.
threats.mitigation:
"Use TLS
All data is verified through the use of schemas and data transformers. Resources use SHA or MD5 hashes to verify integrity."

threats.title: Data Store Denies File System Potentially Writing Data
threats.description: File System claims that it did not write data received from an entity on the other side of the trust boundary. Consider using logging or auditing to record the source, time, and summary of the received data.
threats.mitigation: All file system access is audited.

threats.title: Data Flow Sniffing
threats.description: Data flowing across Retrieve Resource may be sniffed by an attacker. Depending on what type of data an attacker can read, it may be used to attack other parts of the system or simply be a disclosure of information leading to compliance violations. Consider encrypting the data flow.
threats.mitigation: TLS

threats.title: Data Flow Retrieve Resource Is Potentially Interrupted
threats.description: An external agent interrupts data flowing across a trust boundary in either direction.
threats.mitigation: Resources are cached and automatically restarted/retried on failures. DDF is a software system is not responsible for the network.

threats.title: Data Store Inaccessible
threats.description: An external agent prevents access to a data store on the other side of the trust boundary.
threats.mitigation: Resource cache

threats.title: Spoofing the URL Resource Reader Process
threats.description: URL Resource Reader may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to information disclosure by File System. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the destination process.
threats.mitigation: URL Resource Reader is not an external process, it communicates with the Catalog via a service interface.

threats.title: Spoofing of Source Data Store File System
threats.description: File System may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to incorrect data delivered to URL Resource Reader. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the source data store.
threats.mitigation: This is direct file system access on a hardened OS (outside the scope of DDF).

threats.title: Potential Data Repudiation by URL Resource Reader
threats.description: URL Resource Reader claims that it did not receive data from a source outside the trust boundary. Consider using logging or auditing to record the source, time, and summary of the received data.
threats.mitigation: All connections are audited.

threats.title: Weak Access Control for a Resource
threats.description: Improper data protection of File System can allow an attacker to read information not intended for disclosure. Review authorization settings.
threats.mitigation:
"Uses a PDP with XACML for access control
OSGi security manager protects file system by only allowing bundles that need to write to specific areas of the file system permission to do so"

threats.title: Potential Process Crash or Stop for URL Resource Reader
threats.description: URL Resource Reader crashes, halts, stops or runs slowly; in all cases violating an availability metric.
threats.mitigation: URL Resource Reader is not a process on the system, it is a service running within a container that is managing services.

threats.title: Data Flow Response Is Potentially Interrupted
threats.description: An external agent interrupts data flowing across a trust boundary in either direction.
threats.mitigation: DDF is a software system is not responsible for the network.

threats.title: Data Store Inaccessible
threats.description: An external agent prevents access to a data store on the other side of the trust boundary.
threats.mitigation: Resource cache

threats.title: URL Resource Reader May be Subject to Elevation of Privilege Using Remote Code Execution
threats.description: File System may be able to remotely execute code for URL Resource Reader.
threats.mitigation: File system does not execute code.

threats.title: Elevation by Changing the Execution Flow in URL Resource Reader
threats.description: An attacker may pass data into URL Resource Reader in order to change the flow of program execution within URL Resource Reader to the attacker's choosing.
threats.mitigation: All endpoints use standard authentication mechanisms and only operations the user is allowed to carry out are executed.

cells.reasonOutOfScope: Within the trust boundary of the DDF.  These two processes communicate via Java calls on the same JVM.

threats.title: Spoofing the URL Resource Reader Process
threats.description: URL Resource Reader may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to information disclosure by Remote Resource. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the destination process.
threats.mitigation: This is a pluggable component to the Catalog that communicates via a rigidly defined API within the container

threats.title: Spoofing the Remote Resource External Entity
threats.description: Remote Resource may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to unauthorized access to URL Resource Reader. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the external entity.
threats.mitigation: All endpoints use standard authentication mechanisms and TLS

threats.title: Potential Lack of Input Validation for URL Resource Reader
threats.description: Data flowing across Response may be tampered with by an attacker. This may lead to a denial of service attack against URL Resource Reader or an elevation of privilege attack against URL Resource Reader or an information disclosure by URL Resource Reader. Failure to verify that input is as expected is a root cause of a very large number of exploitable issues. Consider all paths and the way they handle data. Verify that all input is verified for correctness using an approved list input validation approach.
threats.mitigation: All input is validated by the Catalog Framework

threats.title: Potential Data Repudiation by URL Resource Reader
threats.description: URL Resource Reader claims that it did not receive data from a source outside the trust boundary. Consider using logging or auditing to record the source, time, and summary of the received data.
threats.mitigation: Catalog framework directly calls URL Resource Reader via a service call, there is no ambiguity as to whether or not it was called.

threats.title: Data Flow Sniffing
threats.description: Data flowing across Response may be sniffed by an attacker. Depending on what type of data an attacker can read, it may be used to attack other parts of the system or simply be a disclosure of information leading to compliance violations. Consider encrypting the data flow.
threats.mitigation: TLS

threats.title: Potential Process Crash or Stop for URL Resource Reader
threats.description: URL Resource Reader crashes, halts, stops or runs slowly; in all cases violating an availability metric.
threats.mitigation: URL Resource Reader is not a process on the system, it is a service running within a container that is managing services.

threats.title: Data Flow Response Is Potentially Interrupted
threats.description: An external agent interrupts data flowing across a trust boundary in either direction.
threats.mitigation: DDF is a software system is not responsible for the network.

threats.title: Elevation Using Impersonation
threats.description: URL Resource Reader may be able to impersonate the context of Remote Resource in order to gain additional privilege.
threats.mitigation: URL Resource Reader executes only with the permissions of the user that is requesting the resource.

threats.title: URL Resource Reader May be Subject to Elevation of Privilege Using Remote Code Execution
threats.description: Remote Resource may be able to remotely execute code for URL Resource Reader.
threats.mitigation: The resource reader does not interpret the resource response, which is just binary.

threats.title: Elevation by Changing the Execution Flow in URL Resource Reader
threats.description: An attacker may pass data into URL Resource Reader in order to change the flow of program execution within URL Resource Reader to the attacker's choosing.
threats.mitigation: All endpoints use standard authentication mechanisms and only operations the user is allowed to carry out are executed.

cells.reasonOutOfScope: Both the Catalog App and the DDF Platform run within the same machine, trust boundary, and JVM.  Communication passing between them is all mitigated via the protections specified for the external facing elements of each app.
Within the trust boundary of the DDF.  These two processes communicate via Java calls on the same JVM.
